description: This session will have the creators of Crate Digging present a 'Behind the Scenes' or 'Making Of' the immersive experience.  This workshop is part of a series of practical events for local people interested in immersive technology.

designers.architect: Uncle 22 and DJ Randall create the hotspot for 160BPM+ beats.

periods: Uncle 22 and DJ Randall create the hotspot for 160BPM+ beats.

factsheet.heading: What is Crate Digging
paragraphs: Crate Digging is a multi-platform immersive experience where we step back into 1991 - De Underground Records, 18 Sebert Road, Forest Gate East London, an inconspicuous record shop and studio - the people, the music, the vibe and the legacy born out of a back street of east London that became the birthplace of Jungle and Drum and Bass music. The spirit of the work is to encouraging a new generation to learn about the technologies and collaborative practices of the 1990s producers and experience the atmosphere.

factsheet.heading: Production Background
paragraphs: in 2021 Rendezvous Productions completed the 1st iteration of Crate Digging as a podcast and audio heritage trail as part of Newham Heritage Month. Hyperactive Development Immersive Producer Atif Ghani reached out to Producer Katherine Green to see where an immersive version of the podcast could be developed. After a successful Arts Council funding applications - Katherine, Atif and Director/Cinematographer Peter Collis began a journey to build a new iteration of Crate Digging as a immersive Virtual Reality experience

factsheet.heading: Technology
paragraphs: Crate Digging began as a podcast and audio trail, but has been morphing into a virtual reality (VR) experience. As part of the building this immersive VR version we were able to complete a filmed shoot of some the original founders of Da Underground Records as a Virtual Production technologies with the support of Target 3D and their LED film stage.  A digital version of De Underground Records was built from found photos and video references.

factsheet.heading: Heritage 4.0
paragraphs: This workshops is part of a series of intensive immersive heritage workshops for a broad range of East London young people and local community (including ethnically diverse, disabled, unemployed and/or low waged, LGBTQ+ communities) to gain exposure in using immersive technologies in the workplace; critical insights into digital and data-driven skills required to succeed in the 21st century.

On the day we will have access to a new VR experience of Crate Digging, but also a A walk around environment where learners will be able to walk around the old De Underground Records store with others live and even field questions from founders and academics about that moment when Jungle Music was formed.
Also the researchers, filmmakers and producing of the different iterations of Crate Digging will be available to field questions and share their insights on the making of our experience.

name: Heritage 4.0: The Case of Crate Digging the Influence of De Underground Records
